data.text:
Before we get to what makes this scene so disturbing, we need a little context first:

So as you might expect, Pinocchio is talked into taking a little trip to Pleasure Island (despite Jiminyâ€™s best efforts to stop him). They join a carriage full to the brim of rowdy boys pulled by eight donkeys (remember that detail). Itâ€™s so crowded in fact, that Pinocchio is sitting up front by the Coachman with an older boy named Lampwick. They bond as kids tend to do when theyâ€™re traveling together and after a long ferry ride to Pleasure Island, the pair stick together once they get inside.

Pleasure Island looks like the worldâ€™s biggest amusement park. Thereâ€™s the typical rides, a Ferris Wheel, and lots of deliciouis food to eat (pies, ice cream, popcorn, etc.) along with other attractions you wouldnâ€™t normally find: a tent devoted to fistfighting, a model house that the boys are free to rip apart, even â€œTobacco Rowâ€ where the boys can have all the cigars they want (remember, this is 1940). And above all the clamor is the repeated sound of voices saying â€œHelp yourselves boys, itâ€™s all FREE, everything is FREE!â€ Jiminy Cricket smells a rat from the start though, but heâ€™s lost Pinocchio in the crowd, so thereâ€™s really nothing he can do at the moment. In all the chaos, nobody notices when the Coachman orders the gates to be shut, remarking ominously â€œgive a boy enough rope, and heâ€™ll make a jackass of himself before long.â€ Itâ€™s an odd comment, but itâ€™s meaning becomes too clear in a few minutes:

After a short scene break, we see that Pleasure Island is now deserted. All the rides are dark, the place is a mess, but thereâ€™s no boys, anywhere! We know they havenâ€™t gone home because even Jiminy is wondering where the boys are. Actually, the place isnâ€™t entirely empty, Pinocchio and Lampwick are busy playing pool while drinking and smoking cigars, but weâ€™ll get back to them in a moment. After Jiminy gets into an argument with the pair, finally telling them to go ahead and â€œmake jackassesâ€ of themselves, he heads to the gate to leave, but on the other side, he hears the sound of donkeysâ€¦.a LOT of donkeys.

Itâ€™s horrifying to hear this little donkey cry â€œI want to go home to my mama!â€ When you know thatâ€™s NEVER going to happen!

Through a crack, Jiminy emerges to find the Coachman and his minions loading crate after crate of donkeys back onto the ferry used to take the boys to the island. What happens next is the first disturbing part of this scene:

As you see, the Coachman is screening the donkeys to see if theyâ€™re still capable of speech. If they bray in response, theyâ€™re stripped of their clothing and sent into an available crate (labeled for the salt mines and the circus, among other places). But in the case of others, like Alexander, who CAN still talk, theyâ€™re sent back to a waiting area, until presumably they lose their ability to speak. This is the moment that disturbs me and breaks my heart: when Alexander is thrown back, you can hear him and the others begging to go home, they donâ€™t WANT to be donkeys, and then the Coachman snaps â€œQUIET!! You boys have had your fun, now PAY for it!â€ Remember earlier when the carnival promised the boys that â€œeverything is free?â€ Of course it wasnâ€™t free, thatâ€™s one of the first lessons we learn in life, but now these boys have to learn it the hard way.

Now back to Pinocchio and Lampwick (this is the REALLY disturbing part): Lampwick is still making fun of Jiminy, when suddenly his ears turn into donkey ears (to Pinocchioâ€™s surprise).

The oblivious Lampwick continues to mock, and then a donkey tail sprouts out!

â€œWhat does he think I look like, a jackass?â€ Lampwick doesnâ€™t realize it, but his face IS that of a donkeyâ€™s now.

Based on Lampwickâ€™s reaction, I think heâ€™d heard stories about Pleasure Island, but had never believed them (hence his cry â€œIâ€™ve been double crossed (betrayed)â€, I bet the Coachman assured him those stories were lies.)

Pinocchio laughingly tells him he does until his laugh changes into a donkey bray. Lampwick finds that funny until HE brays too. Then, Lampwick realizes that something is wrong with HIM! â€œWhatâ€¦whatâ€™s going on?â€ he asks desperately as he feels his changed face and discovers he has long donkey ears. And thenâ€¦he sees his face in the mirror and screams â€œIâ€™ve been double crossed!! Help! Help!! Somebody help!!â€ Lampwick is running through the pool hall desperately but thereâ€™s nothing anyone can do. Pinocchio can only watch in horror as the rest of Lampwickâ€™s body begins to change (an especially horrifying part is when Lampwickâ€™s hands, clawing at Pinocchio for ANY kind of help, turn into hooves before the puppetâ€™s terrified eyes).

Lampwickâ€™s final change is a disturbing moment, especially since you can hear him fighting against losing the power to speak as a human

And then, like a scene straight out of a horror movie, we see Lampwickâ€™s final change in silhouette. With a final cry of â€œMama, MAMA!!!â€ Lampwick is forced down to all fours and begins frantically braying, kicking and smashing everything in sight. Itâ€™s a horrifying fate for anyone to experience, but these are all young kids that are now condemned to a lifetime of cruel torture and servitude. Thereâ€™s no happy ending for these boys, not even a glimmer of hope. And the same fate nearly comes to Pinocchio as well as HE begins to change also (though noticeably heâ€™s changing into a GRAY donkey, everyone else turned brown.) Fortunately, Jiminy finds Pinocchio in time and the pair flee the cursed island quickly enough that Pinocchio only has donkey ears and a tail.

What a horrifying, disturbing fate for all those little boys. And just imagine all the families who are waiting for children that will never come home? The more you think about the situation, the more disturbing it becomes. And remember at the beginning when I pointed out the coach was drawn by donkeys? I have no doubt that the Coachman uses boys-turned-int0-donkeys to help carry more boys to Pleasure Island for the same fate. Oh the disturbing irony of it all. Without a doubt, THIS is one of the most disturbing moments in all of Disney animation, not just because of Lampwickâ€™s terrified reaction to his transformation, but also because these hundreds of boys are left to their fate, with no hope of rescue.

Next time will be one more example from Pinocchio; see, even though heâ€™s escaped Pleasure Island, Pinocchio isnâ€™t out of danger yet. Thatâ€™s because his father Geppetto has been swallowed by a whaleâ€¦

I think it should go without saying that Pinocchio is one of the most disturbing Disney movies ever created. It will certainly occupy quite a few places in this series (which is why Iâ€™m starting out with it), and one of the most disturbing parts of this film is the character of the Coachman (voiced by Charles Judels, who coincidentally also voices Stromboli in the same film).

The Coachman is introduced about halfway through the film. At a sleepy tavern one night, the tricksters â€œHonestâ€ John (a fox) and Gideon (a cat) are regaling the Coachman with how they tricked Pinocchio into going with Stromboli, the latter paying them a (tiny) modest fee in return. The Coachman appears bemused by all of this, and finally asks the two if theyâ€™d like to make some REAL money, thumping down an enormous bag of money on the table. To get paid, all Honest John and Gideon have to do is find as many naughty boys as they can and direct them to a coach that he has leaving at midnight. A few of the details are obscured in whispers, but the conclusion is that by the end of it all, the Coachman will be taking all the boys off to Pleasure Island.

â€œPLEASURE ISLAND?!!?â€ Honest John appears petrified for once and questions what will happen if the law finds out?? (Note how the music rises in â€œpanicâ€ along with Honest Johnâ€™s words). Given the disregard for the law Honest John has shown before, it speaks volumes that heâ€™s worried about it now. But the Coachman isnâ€™t worried as thereâ€™s no risk: â€œYou seeâ€¦â€ he says â€œthey never come backâ€¦as BOYS!!!â€

THIS is what makes this a â€œDisturbing Disneyâ€ scene, not just the Coachmanâ€™s threat about the boys never returning (as humans) but also his unexpected transformation into this monstrous/demonic figure. When I re-watched the film for the first time in many years, I literally leaped back in my seat as I hadnâ€™t remembered this part at all!! Itâ€™s a truly disturbing moment that makes the skin crawl. Clearly, the Coachman isnâ€™t an ordinary human, in fact, I donâ€™t think heâ€™s human at all! Based on what weâ€™ll see in the second installment, I think it likely that the Coachman is a literal â€œdevil in disguiseâ€ (he is wearing red after all) or at the very least heâ€™s a dark spirit working in league with the devil.

One last note, I just wanted to mention my thoughts on something I read while researching for this post: for those who say that this scene is a metaphor for pedophilia (i.e. they never come back as â€œboysâ€ because heâ€™s going to use them in THAT way, etc.), I would say consider WHEN this film was made. Iâ€™m not saying that issue didnâ€™t exist in 1940, but films were still highly censored when it came to taboo subjects and if the review board had the slightest inkling thatâ€™s what this moment referred to, the scene would have been cut for sure (or the line would have been altered). Thatâ€™s all I wanted to say about that; I believe the Coachmanâ€™s words can be interpreted literally, theyâ€™re not coming back as â€œboysâ€ because theyâ€™re not going to be human when they return.

And to think this is found in a movie watched by childrenâ€¦*shudders* and if you think THIS is bad, just wait until #2, thatâ€™s when Iâ€™ll tell you the secret of Pleasure Island (and what happens to Pinocchioâ€™s friend Lampwickâ€¦I nearly started with this scene instead but I thought it would be better to build up to it.)

What do you think of the first installment of â€œDisturbing Disneyâ€ ? I promise Iâ€™ve got plenty more to share with you. I canâ€™t wait to see Logan tonight and share my thoughts on it with you ğŸ™‚

At the conclusion of â€œSavages, Part Iâ€, the English settlers and the warriors led by Powhatan were preparing for battle (with the latter planning to execute John Smith first thing in the morning). Meanwhile, Pocahontas has fled to Grandmother Willow, upset and depressed that everything is falling apart and the man sheâ€™s so recently fallen in love with is going to be executed and thereâ€™s nothing she can do to stop it.

Pocahontas â€œSavages, Part IIâ€ (1995)

Grandmother Willow tries to give some advice, reminding Pocahontas of her dream, but she isnâ€™t in the mood to hear it. Meeko, however, is inspired to dig inside his hole in the tree for something.

This â€œsomethingâ€ turns out to be John Smithâ€™s compass, which contains a large arrow shaped needle inside (Meeko had swiped it during an earlier meeting and Smith had let the raccoon keep it). Pocahontas watches the compass and realizes that as she turns it in her hands, the arrow/needle spins, just like the arrow in her dream!!

From the moment Pocahontas picked the compass up, the music has begun to pick up in intensity (clearly signalling that something big is about to happen). When she makes the connection between the compass needle and her dream, it picks up a little more. At the peak, there is a short, instrumental refrain of â€œListen With Your Heartâ€ as several things happen at once: the sun rises (itâ€™s time for the execution) and the compass needle comes to a stop pointing directly east. The meaning is clear: Pocahontas needs to stop the execution.

With this decision made, the song resumes with an abrupt cut to Ratcliffe literally walking out of the sunrise, cutting a villainous figure in his black armor. At the same time, Powhatan and his warriors begin the march to the execution site (with Smith in tow) while, in a THIRD musical thread, Pocahontas begins her run to stop an all-out war!

And, according to the song, Pocahontas truthfully doesnâ€™t know if she can stop this war from happening, but with the power of the spirits (which she invokes along the way), sheâ€™s certainly going to try. This semi-hopeful verse is sharply contrasted with the two warring sides who are basically singing the same words (so Iâ€™m copying the verse in full):

(Them:)This will be the day/This will be the morning/We will see them dying in the dust

(Pocahontas): I donâ€™t know what I can do/still I know I have to try

(Them):Now we make them pay!

(Pocahontas): Eagle help my feet fly!/(Them): Now without a warning

(Pocahontas): Mountain help my heart be great/(Them): Now we leave â€™em blood and bone and dust

(Pocahontas):Spirits of the Earth and Sky/(Them): Itâ€™s them, or us

(Pocahontas): Please donâ€™t let it be too late!!/Them: Theyâ€™re just a bunch of filthy, stinkingâ€¦

(Them): Savages, savages/demons, devils (kill them!)/savages, savages, what are we waiting for? Destroy their evil race, until thereâ€™s no a trace left!

(Pocahontas): How loud are the drums of war!!/Them: Now we see what comes, of trying to be chums/ Pocahontas: Is this the death of all I love, carried in the drumming ofâ€¦

(All): WAR!!!

Towards the end, all three groups converge at a cliff where the tribe has assembled to execute Smith as revenge for Kocuomâ€™s death. While the approaching settlers watch in horror, Powhatan prepares to crush Smithâ€™s skull with a war hammer (a club with a large stone set in it). At the last moment, Pocahontas darts forward and throws herself over Smith before the hammer can fall.

Saved!!! For now anyway. Pocahontas has an ultimatum: if Powhatan wants to kill John Smith, he has to kill her too, and also she loves him (to the surprise of her father). All of this, Pocahontas says, is the result of walking a path of anger. She, meanwhile, will choose love.

Moved by what his daughter has said, and seeing the slaughter that will come if they continue, Powhatan swears that if there will be any more killing â€œit will not start with meâ€ and he orders Smith to be released. Everyone begins to lower their weapons, and war seems to have been avertedâ€¦which is greatâ€¦right?

Ratcliffe doesnâ€™t think so. This was his big chance to take the Indians out and now the battle isnâ€™t happening at all!. He tries to take advantage by shouting for his men to fire, but the settlers arenâ€™t having it. The whole point of attacking was to rescue Smith, but the tribe has let him go so clearly they donâ€™t want to fight (and therefore neither should they). Seeing his control slip away, Ratcliffe decides to force the issue, grabbing a musket and taking aim at Powhatan. Smith sees this and shoves the chief out of the way just as Ratcliffe fires, taking the bullet instead. Instead of sparking a new conflict, this backfires horribly and Ratcliffe finds him at the receiving end of the settlersâ€™ wrath (a great comeuppance for Ratcliffe by the way, since he ends up being hog-tied by the end).

So on the one hand, the day is saved, but on the other, John is badly injured. This is one Disney film that wonâ€™t have the typical ending. How do I mean? Well, youâ€™ll have to check out the finale to find out ğŸ™‚

It nearly goes without saying that â€œSavages, Parts I and IIâ€ are one of my favorite Disney songs and I hope you enjoyed reading about it and listening to it.

I wanted to save this song for last, but I couldnâ€™t hold out any longer!!!

With practically every Disney film ever made, there comes a point where events spiral out of control and everything is on the verge of disaster!! â€œSavages, Part Iâ€ begins at such a moment: Kocuom is dead at the hands of Thomas, but only Pocahontas and John Smith know that. The warriors who capture Smith assume that, as the only white man present, that HE fired the shot, and even if Pocahontas told them the truth, they wouldnâ€™t believe her. Chief Powhatan is beyond disappointed in his daughter and he also blames her for Kocuomâ€™s death (â€œbecause of YOUR foolishness, Kocuom is dead!â€)

Pocahontas â€œSavages Part Iâ€ (1995)

But the turmoil in the village is nothing compared to whatâ€™s brewing in the English camp. Thomas has gone racing back to report Smithâ€™s capture, rousing everyone in the process. Ratcliffe is secretly delighted by this turn of events; heâ€™s been itching for any excuse for an all out attack on the â€œsavagesâ€ and this provides the perfect opportunity.

â€œSavagesâ€ begins with Ratcliffe stirring the settlers into a frenzy, reminding them that these â€œsavagesâ€ are no good, they deserve to die because theyâ€™re different, etc.For example:

What can you expect/from filthy little heathens/hereâ€™s what you get when races are diverse!

Their skinâ€™s a hellish red/theyâ€™re only good when dead/theyâ€™re vermin as Iâ€™ve said and worse!!

Actually, the soundtrack version of the song is much nastier, the opening line goes: â€¦from filthy little heathens/their whole disgusting race is like a curse! (I think they realized when they developed this song, that they were going a step too far and they adjusted the line for the home video release of the film.)

Theses opening verses are so openly racist that in the years since its release, this song in particular has gotten a lot of flak, with critics saying the songâ€™s sentiments are completely inappropriate.While is is true that â€œSavagesâ€ expresses racist sentiments, thatâ€™s also the point of the entire song!! This song is fully exposing Ratcliffe as the evil, racist villain heâ€™s always been, and the settlers are fully caught up in the wake of his ranting (except for Thomas, who has his own doubts).

Theyâ€™re savages!

Savages! Barely even human!

Savages! Savages! Drive them from our shore!

Theyâ€™re not like you and me, which means they must be evil

We must sound the drums of war!

Theyâ€™re savages!

Savages!

Dirty shrieking devils!

Now we sound the drums of war!

With the English settlers ramped up to go to war, the song switches to Powhatanâ€™s village, where the villagers are making preparations of their own. While the English consider the Indians to be â€œsavagesâ€, the natives consider the white men to be â€œdemonsâ€ who must be wiped out before anyone else can die.

This is what we feared/the pale-face is a demon/the only thing they feel at all is greed.

Beneath that milky hide/thereâ€™s emptiness inside/I wonder if they even bleed??

Theyâ€™re savages! Savages!

Barely even human! Savages! Savages!

Killers at the coreâ€¦

Theyâ€™re different from us,

which means they canâ€™t be trustedâ€¦

We must sound the drums of war!

Theyâ€™re savages!

Savages!

First we deal with this one

Then we sound the drums of war!

John Smith can only watch as the war preparations continue, with the Indians planning to execute him before the battle. The camera cuts back and forth to show how alike the two sides really are: both are arming for war, both are really angry and both are beating â€œthe drums of warâ€ (no matter how different they look, a drum is a drum.)

The truth is, both sides are blinded by hatred. Neither can see that they are equally human because one looks different from the other. Itâ€™s interesting how, in the song, each side is color-coded and made to look increasingly not-human (the English are colored orange/crimson and the Indians are colored indigo with war paint added on top of it).

Things are definitely out of control, and if the two sides meet, itâ€™s going to be bad (mostly for the Indians, because the English settlers have a lot of muskets and cannons and arrows and spears will have practically zero effect on that kind of firepower.) Whatâ€™s going to happen? Will John Smith die at sunrise? Weâ€™ll find out in â€œSavages, Part IIâ€ !!!!

I canâ€™t say it often enough: Atlantis: The Lost Empire is one of the most underrated films that Disney has ever made. Seriously, the animation is beautiful, the story is great, and the MUSIC is one of the best parts! (See Atlantis: The Lost Empire â€œThe Crystal Chamberâ€ for more of my thoughts on this score).

If you havenâ€™t seen the film, the story follows a young cartographer and linguist named Milo Thatch (Michael J. Fox), who is determined to prove the lost city of Atlantis (whose destruction we witness in the beginning of the film) exists and thereby clear his grandfatherâ€™s name (his late grandfather was a famous explorer who lost his reputation when he insisted that Atlantis was real). According to Thatchâ€™s research, the key to discovering the location of the sunken city can be found in a mysterious artifact known as The Shepherdâ€™s Journal. But as it turns out, his grandfather had already found the Journal in a previous expedition and left it to his friend, eccentric millionaire Preston B. Whitmore, to be held in his possession until Milo was â€œreadyâ€ to find Atlantis himself. Whitmore wants to help Milo because of a bet he made with his grandfather over whether or not Atlantis existed. Since Miloâ€™s grandfather found the Journal, Whitmore agreed to finance any future expedition with the best materials and the best crew. To that end, Milo is introduced to mostly the same crew that helped Miloâ€™s grandfather find the Journal in Iceland.

The most notable members include:

Tiberius Roarke: Commander and secretly a snake in the grass who wants to rob Atlantis of its treasures for huge profits

Helga Sinclair: Roarkeâ€™s lieutenant (and possibly some-time lover?) who is also in this for the profits (though she does express brief reservations when they discover Atlantis is still inhabited)

Vinny Santorini: a demolitions expert obsessed with making things go BOOM! Previously worked in a flower shop (though heâ€™d prefer you didnâ€™t know that)

Gaeton Moliere (better known as â€œMoleâ€), a geologist with an unhealthy dirt obsession. A line in the direct-to-video sequel implies he was raised by naked mole rats.

Dr. Joshua Strongbear: a doctor of African-American/Native American descent. He talks a lot but has a really good heart when push comes to shove.

Audrey Ramirez: A teenage mechanic from Puerto Rico and the youngest member on the expedition. If it has an engine, she can make it run. Her sister is a famous boxer.

â€œCookieâ€: The expedition cook (though that term is used very loosely) who believes in HIS basic food groups: â€œbeans, bacon, whiskey and lard.â€

After numerous hurdles (including having their main ship blown to pieces by a mechanical Leviathan), the surviving crew arrive at Atlantis and are stunned to discover a living city inhabited by hundreds (if not more) of people. The surviving Atlanteans are still ruled by King Kashekim Nedakh (who was king when Atlantis sank under the sea) and his only daughter Kidagakash or â€œKidaâ€ is heir to the throne. Roarke successfully bargains for the crew to stay the night in the city and Milo goes off to explore with Kida, who is fascinated to meet someone from the surface. Predictably, things go sour when it turns out that Roarke and the rest of the crew are actually mercenaries that have a taste for pillaging ancient treasures for profit. In this case, theyâ€™re after the semi-mystical â€œHeart of Atlantis,â€ the crystal that is currently keeping the city and its inhabitants alive. Kida is absorbed into the Crystal after Roarke deduces its location and Milo gives chase to bring her back before the entire city dies. After a lengthy battle (in which Roarke, Helga and the rest of the crew who didnâ€™t side with Milo are killed), Milo decides to stay in Atlantis with Kida while Audrey, Cookie, and the rest of our heroes return to the surface (with an Atlantean ship filled to the brim with treasure as their reward for doing the right thing).

This film was my first exposure to James Newton Howard (The Hunger Games series, Maleficent), and I will defend this score forever. That being said, I was beyond happy when I stumbled across this interview on YouTube where Howard talks about his work on this film. And as Howard puts it, there are really two films going on in this story: thereâ€™s the action/adventure of finding Atlantis, and once our hero Milo arrives, a totally new story begins (with a new score to match). To help distinguish Atlantis musically, Howard used a variety of Balinese instruments (which favor bells and gongs) to create a very unique sound.

I hope you enjoy listening to this interview with James Newton Howard! If you also enjoy this film, let me know what you like about it ğŸ™‚

Warning!!! This review spoils EVERYTHING about Rogue One, if you havenâ€™t seen the film and DONâ€™T want to know, stop reading NOW!!!

Still here? Okay, continue!! (But remember, you were warned!!)

Oh my gosh, oh my gosh, OH.MY.GOSH!!! Thursday night, 9:45 p.m., the long wait finally ended and I saw Rogue One: A Star Wars Story, the first stand-alone Star Wars film in the Anthology series. And oh boy did it deliver!! The film does have one flaw, but Iâ€™ll get to that after a bit, letâ€™s start with one of the best parts of the filmâ€¦

DARTH VADER IS BACK!!!

Letâ€™s all be honest, I think most of us who have gone to see this film did it because Vader was showing up (I know that certainly helped to sway my decision).
